[[File:Range_of_Neanderthals_in_the_Levant.png|400px|right|thumb|The known range of Neanderthals in Southwest Asia (orange) and elsewhere.]]
'''Southwest Asian Neanderthals''' are [[Neanderthals]] that lived in Turkey, Lebanon, Israel, Syria, Iraq, and Iran, the southernmost expanse of their known range. Although their arrival in Asia is not well-dated, early Neanderthals occupied the region apparently until about 100,000 years ago. At this time, ''[[Homo sapiens]]'' seems to have replaced them in one of the [[Recent African origin of modern humans|first anatomically modern expansions out of Africa]]. In their turn, starting around 80,000 years ago, Neanderthals seem to have replaced ''[[Homo sapiens]]'' in Southwest Asia. They inhabited the region until about 55,000 years ago.<ref name="Been2017a"/>
In Southwest Asia, Neanderthals left well-preserved skeletal remains in Israel, Syria, and Iraq. Remains in Turkey, Lebanon, and Iran are fragmentary. No Neanderthal skeletal remain has ever been found to the south of Jerusalem, and although there are [[Middle Palaeolithic]] [[Levallois technique|Levallois]] points in Jordan and in the Arabian peninsula, it is unclear whether these were made by Neanderthals or [[anatomically modern humans]].<ref name="Been2017a">{{cite journal |author1=E. Been|author2=E. Hovers|author3=R. Ekshtain|author4=A. Malinski-Buller|author5=N. Agha|author6=A. Barash|author7=D.E. Bar-Yosef Mayer|author8=S. Benazzi|author9=[[Jean-Jacques Hublin|J.-J. Hublin]]|author10=L. Levin|author11=N. Greenbaum|author12=N. Mitki|author13=G. Oxilia|author14=N. Porat|author15=J. Roskin|author16=M. Soudack|author17=R. Yeshurun|author18=R. Shahack-Gross|author19=N. Nir|author20=M.C. Stahlschmidt|author21=Y. Rak|author22=O. Barzilai|display-authors=10|date= 2017|title= The first Neanderthal remains from an open-air Middle Palaeolithic site in the Levant|url= |journal= Scientific Reports|volume=7|issue=2958|doi= 10.1038/s41598-017-03025-z}}{{open access}}</ref> Neanderthals further to the east, such as those found in Uzbekistan<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|author=A. Okladnikov|title=Исследование мустьерской стоянки и погребеня неандертальца в гроте Тешик-Таш, Южный Узбекистан (Средняя Азия)|trans-title=Investigation of the Mousterian site and burial of a Neanderthal in the cave of Teshik-Tash, Southern Uzbekistan (Central Asia)|encyclopedia=Тешик-Таш. Палеолитический человек|language=Russian|location=Moscow|pages=7–85|year=1949}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=Michelle Glantz|author2=Bence Viola|author3=Patrick Wrinn|author4=Tatiana Chikisheva|author5=Anatoly Derevianko|author6=Andrei Krivoshapkin|author7=Uktur Islamov|author8=Rustam Suleimanov|author9=Terrence Ritzman|title=New hominin remains from Uzbekistan|journal=Journal of Human Evolution|volume=55|issue=2|pages=223–237|year=2008}}</ref> and Asian Russia<ref>{{cite journal|author1=M.B. Mednikova|title=A proximal pedal phalanx of a Paleolithic hominin from Denisova Cave, Altai|volume=39|issue=1|pages=129–138|journal=Archaeology, Ethnology and Anthropology of Eurasia|year=2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|author1=B. Viola|author2=S.V. Markin|author3=A.P. Buzhilova|author4=M.B. Mednikova|author5=A. Le Cabec|author6=M.V. Shunkov|display-authors=et al.|title=New Neanderthal remains from Chagyrskaya Cave (Altai Mountains, Russian Federation)|journal=American Journal of Physical Anthropology|volume=147|issue=Suppl. 54|pages=293–294|url=http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/ajpa.22033/pdf|access-date=11 June 2017}}</ref> are known as Central and North Asian Neanderthals.
As of 2013, although many more Neanderthal remains have been discovered in Southwest Asia than in North Asia, where genetic studies have succeeded,<ref name="Prufer2014">{{cite journal|author1=K. Prüfer|author2= F. Racimo|author3= N. Patterson|author4= F. Jay|author5= S. Sankararaman|author6= S. Sawyer|author7= A. Heinze|author8= G. Renaud|author9= P.H. Sudmant|author10= C. de Filippo|author11= H. Li|author12= S. Mallick|author13= M. Dannemann|author14= Q. Fu|author15= M. Kircher|author16= M. Kuhlwilm|author17= M. Lachmann|author18= M. Meyer|author19= M. Ongyerth|author20= M. Siebauer|author21= C. Theunert|author22= A. Tandon|author23= P. Moorjani|author24= J. Pickrell|author25= J.C. Mullikin|author26= S.H. Vohr|author27= R.E. Green|author28= I. Hellmann|author29= P.L.F. Johnson|author30= H. Blanche|author31= Howard Cann|author32= J.O. Kitzman|author33= J. Shendure|author34= E.E. Eichler|author35= E.S. Lein|author36= T.E. Bakken|author37= L.V. Golovanova|author38= V.B. Doronichev|author39= M.V. Shunkov|author40= A.P. Derevianko|author41= B. Viola|author42= M. Slatkin|author43= D. Reich|author44= J. Kelso|author45= [[Svante Pääbo|S. Pääbo]]|display-authors=10|date= 2014|title=The complete genome sequence of a Neanderthal from the Altai Mountains|journal= Nature|volume= 505|pages= 43–49|doi=10.1038/nature12886|pmid=24352235|pmc=4031459}}{{paywall}}</ref> no attempt at extracting DNA from Southwest Asian Neanderthals has ever been successful.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=J. Hawks|title=Significance of Neandertal and Denisovan Genomes in Human Evolution|journal=Annual Review of Anthropology|volume=42|pages=433–449|year=2013|doi=10.1146/annurev-anthro-092412-155548}}</ref> <!--==Anatomy== A large number of scholarly sources claim, without using statistical tests, that Southwest Asian Neanderthals were anatomically different from their European counterparts. But after extensive statistical testing I could not find a single trait that proved significantly different. I refuse to write this section. --[[N.P.|Nicolas Perrault III]] -->
==Early hominins (to 100 ka)== {{See also|Out of Africa I}} As the Levant is the landbridge to Eurasia, Dmanisi remains in Georgia from 1.81 Ma suggest that hominins passed through the Levant some time before this (unless they crossed the [[Bab el-Mandeb]] strait into Arabia). The oldest known hominin specimen from the Levant, and from all the Middle East, is the [[Mugharet el-Zuttiyeh|Zuttiyeh skull]], found by [[Francis Turville-Petre]] near the Sea of Galilee in 1927. It has not been dated, but lithic industries suggest it dates from 250-350 ka (Bar-Yosef 1992).<ref name="Bar-Yosef1992">Bar-Yosef, O. (1992). The role of western Asia in modern human origins. Philosophical Transactions: Biological Sciences, 337(1280), 193–200.</ref> Though it has some modern characteristics, it has been classified as a specimen of ''[[Homo heidelbergensis]]''.
Other known hominin fossils in Southwest Asia older than 100 ka include [[Shanidar Cave|Shanidar]] 2 and 4, as well as Tabun C1. All three have at one point been classified as Neanderthals, although the latter two are now usually called pre-Neanderthals. In part because none are well-dated these attributions have all been challenged.
== Early AMHs in the Levant (100 to 80 ka) == {{See also|Skhul and Qafzeh hominins}} It is believed that anatomically modern humans first entered the Levant by 130 – 100 ka (Grün 2005)<ref name="Grun2005">Grün, R., Stringer, C., McDermott, F., Nathan, R., Porat, N., Robertson, S., … McCulloch, M. (2005). U-series and ESR analyses of bones and teeth relating to the human burials from Skhul. Journal of Human Evolution, 49(3), 316–334. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhevol.2005.04.006</ref> from Africa during the Last Interglacial, a hot, parched, period in Africa (Scholz et al. 2007).
===Environment=== Goat [[δ13C|δ<sup>13</sup>C]] values from c. 92 ka collected at [[Kedumim Cave|Qafzeh Cave]] show that goats were eating, depending on the season, between 20 and 50% of [[C4 carbon fixation|C<sub>4</sub> plants]]. These plants are better adapted to dry and hot climates than the much more common [[C3 carbon fixation|C<sub>3</sub> plants]]. Although it was already established that North Africa was arid in the early Last Glacial, Scholz et al. (2007)'s conclusions would extend this to the Levant, making the region in this period more arid than previously thought.{{Verify source|date=June 2017|reason=I wrote this in December 2016, wrote down the source in Harvard style, but can't seem to find it. Any help appreciated.}} Frumkin et al. (2011)<ref>Frumkin, A., Bar-Yosef, O., & Schwarcz, H. P. (2011). Possible paleohydrologic effect on hominin migration and occupation of the Levantine Middle Paleolithic. Journal of Human Evolution2, 60(4), 437–451. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhevol.2010.03.010</ref> arrived at a similar conclusion of a hot and arid Levant{{when|date=June 2017}} by examining changes through time of lake levels and in the formation of [[speleothems|cave formations]].
== Return of Neanderthals to the Levant (80 to 55 ka) ==
Potential causes for the initial extinction of modern humans from the Levant and subsequent replacement by Neanderthals around 80 ka include a short-term extreme environmental change in the Levant and environmental changes in the regions neighbouring the Levant. The only long-term environmental change that has been found in the Levant at this period is an increase in rainfall (Hallin et al. 2012),<ref name="Hallin2012"/> and some moderate cooling of the region (Bar-Yosef 1992,<ref name="Bar-Yosef1992"/> Harrison and Bates 1991),<ref>Harrison, D. L., & Bates, P. J. J. (1991). Felidae. In The mammals of Arabia (2nd ed., pp. 156–172). Sevenoaks: Harrison Zoological Museum.</ref> which would not predict a hominin extinction (Hallin et al. 2012).<ref name="Hallin2012">Hallin, K. A., Schoeninger, M. J., & Schwarcz, H. P. (2012). Paleoclimate during Neandertal and anatomically modern human occupation at Amud and Qafzeh, Israel: the stable isotope data. Journal of Human Evolution, 62(1), 59–73. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.jhevol.2011.09.005</ref> Hence, a short-lived intense environmental change (such as a [[volcanic winter]] of 6 to 1000 years caused by the Toba supereruption, Rampino and Self 1992)<ref>Rampino, M. R., & Self, S. (1992). Volcanic Winter and accelerated glaciation following the Toba super-eruption. Nature, 369(6390), 50–52. http://doi.org/10.1038/359050a0</ref> might have cause modern human extinction, especially if the modern human Levantine population was low (Shea 2008).<ref name = "Shea2008">Shea, J. J. (2008). Transitions or turnovers ? Climatically-forced extinctions of Homo sapiens and Neanderthals in the East Mediterranean Levant. Quaternary Science Reviews, 1–18. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.quascirev.2008.08.015</ref> In this case, Neanderthals could have moved in during or after the modern human evacuation of the region.
Alternatively, climate change could have connected the Neanderthal biome to the north, allowing Neanderthals to replace modern humans if Neanderthals were better pre-adapted to the new Levantine environment. It is also possible for climate change to have allowed the North African desert to expand and cut off the modern human Levantine biome from the larger African one. This could have driven to extinction the modern human population with too few individuals to survive when disconnected from Africa, allowing Neanderthals to walk into the region. This could have happened even if modern humans were better adapted to the region than Neanderthals. In other words, in this case, the only advantage Neanderthals would have had in the Levant is that they could actually get there.
=== Environment ===
Contrarily to modern humans who arrived in the Levant in period particularly warm in both Eurasia and Africa, Neanderthals are thought to have entered the Levant in a period of increasing Eurasian coldness and aridity known as the Last Glacial Period (Tchernov 1989).<ref>Tchernov, E. (1989). The Middle Paleolithic mammalian sequence and its bearing on the origin of Homo sapiens in the southern Levant. In O. Bar-Yosef & B. Vandermeersch (Eds.), Investigations in South Levantine Prehistory (pp. 25–42). Oxford: Archaeopress.</ref> In the Levant, however, the conditions would have been wetter than those of today and of the preceding interglacial. This is what Hallin et al. (2012)<ref name="Hallin2012"/> concluded in their study of the [[δ13C|δ<sup>13</sup>C]] and [[δ18O|δ<sup>18</sup>O]]<ref group=Note>δ<sup>13</sup>C and δ<sup>18</sup>O are so-called [[isotopic signatures]]. They respectively measure the prevalence of the heavier [[carbon-13]] (<sup>13</sup>C) and [[oxygen-18]] (<sup>18</sup>O) [[isotopes]] over the more common [[carbon-12]] and [[oxygen-16]]. [[C4 carbon fixation|C<sub>4</sub>-pathway plants]] have relatively more <sup>13</sup>C (higher δ<sup>13</sup>C) than [[C3 carbon fixation|C<sub>3</sub>-pathway plants]]. Because C<sub>4</sub> plants are better adapted to hot and dry climates than C<sub>3</sub> plants, high δ<sup>13</sup>C values are associated with hot and dry environments.
To the contrary, a greater prevalence of <sup>18</sup>O (higher δ<sup>18</sup>O) in (land) animal bones reflects a colder environment: Because <sup>16</sup>O is lighter than <sup>18</sup>O, water molecules of the form H<sub>2</sub><sup>16</sup>O evaporate slightly more readily than those of the H<sub>2</sub><sup>18</sup>O form. This difference in evaporation is greater the colder the environment gets, so that rain and snow in colder regions have a lower δ<sup>18</sup>O value. Animals incorporate the δ<sup>13</sup>C and δ<sup>18</sup>O information of their environment and it is possible to extract it from their bones and teeth.</ref> values of goat and gazelle enamel from Amud cave in Neanderthals layers dated to 70-53 ka (Glacial Period), after comparing them to values from Qafzeh cave in a modern human layer dated to 92 ka. They found that at Amud, neither the goats nor the gazelle consumed arid-adapted C<sub>4</sub> plants, indicating that the environment was not as dry as today. They found the magnitude and pattern of δ<sup>18</sup>O values in gazelle and goat teeth enamel to indicate that, unlike today, rain fell throughout the year at Amud in the Neanderthal period. Indeed, the variation in δ<sup>18</sup>O values in the oldest layers of the teeth, formed when the animal is only a few months old, suggested that goats and gazelles were born throughout the year, which today happens only in the Levant in wetter-than-normal conditions.
Belmaker et al. (2011)<ref name = "Belmaker2011">Belmaker, M., & Hovers, E. (2011). Ecological change and the extinction of the Levantine Neanderthals: implications from a diachronic study of micromammals from Amud Cave, Israel. Quaternary Science Reviews, 30, 3196–3209. http://doi.org/10.1016/j.quascirev.2011.08.001</ref> compared the prevalence in caves of microfaunal bones brought back by Barn and Eagle owls, which are known to accumulate large quantities of rodent skeletons. Since owls are opportunistic hunters and will eat any small mammal, the bone assemblage they leave behind are thought to be accurate indicators of the environment, given that rodents, like beetles, are susceptible to small changes in temperature and humidity. The researchers did find changes in microfaunal bone assemblages, but all were expected by taphonomic bias. They therefore concluded that there were no significant changes in the environment of the Levant between 70 and 55 ka.
== Return of AMHs to the Levant (after 55 ka) ==
{{See also|Neanderthal extinction}} Unless modern humans started expanding into Eurasia through Arabia (where stone tools but very few human bones have been found), the Levant is most likely the first ground Neanderthals have lost in the face of expanding modern humans. The youngest Neanderthal specimen in the Levant is about 45,000 years old. From there on Neanderthals seem to have retreated all the way to the Atlantic over a period of about 2500 to 5000 years. Neanderthals would then have [[Neanderthal extinction|gone extinct]], as there seems to be no evidence of Neanderthals anywhere in their range after 40,000 BP.
It is unclear why Neanderthals abandoned the Levant or lost it to modern humans. Shea (2008)<ref name = "Shea2008"/> has argued that Neanderthals were climatically forced out of the region (as modern humans probably were about 75,000 years ago). This is contested. Belmaker et al. (2011)<ref name="Belmaker2011"/> have found that the proportions of microfaunal bones in the Levant between 70 and 55 ka seem stable, despite the fact that small fauna are sensitive to slight changes in temperature or humidity. There would be hence little reason to believe in a slow deterioration of the Neanderthal habitat driving them out by 45 ka. It is possible that climate change drove Neanderthals to extinction quickly some time after 55,000 BP, but Hallin et al. (2012)<ref name="Hallin2012"/> found strong consistency through time in the [[δ13C|δ<sup>13</sup>C]] and [[δ18O|δ<sup>18</sup>O]] values in the teeth of both goats and gazelles, suggesting that the climate was stable in the Levant at this crucial period when Middle Palaeolithic technologies of Neanderthals and early modern humans were replaced by Upper Palaeolithic technology of later modern humans.
Although the environment at this period in the Levant seems to have been stable, Shea (2008)<ref name = "Shea2008"/> suggested that a rapidly changing environment at the border between the Levant and the Sinai could have stimulated the development of the first Upper Palaeolithic technologies. In this scenario, modern humans would only have been able to displace Neanderthals once they had developed this technology. The advanced tools found in Europe in the millennia thereafter would have developed there and then.
== Resource gathering strategy == It is believed that Neanderthals and modern humans in the Levant had different resource gathering behaviours. Lieberman and Shea (1994)<ref>Lieberman, D. E., & Shea, J. J. (1994). Behavioral Differences between Archaic and Modern Humans in the Levantine Mousterian. American Anthropologist, 96(2), 300–332. http://doi.org/10.1525/aa.1994.96.2.02a00030</ref> analysed their lithic hunting technologies and found their differences to suggest Neanderthals hunted more frequently than modern humans. They argue that Neanderthals would have used their intensive hunting strategy to cope with a biodepleted environment, much like the Inuit of the 20th century used to depend largely on hunting. Henry et al. (2017)<ref>{{cite journal|author1=D.O. Henry|author2=M. Belmaker|author3=S.M. Bergin|title=The effect of terrain on Neanderthal ecology in the Levant|journal=Quaternary International|volume=435|issue=Part A|year=2017|pages=94–105|doi=10.1016/j.quaint.2015.10.023}}</ref> found that in the Levant the site exploitation territory of Neanderthals was narrow, as they limited themselves to rugged woodlands, while modern humans of the Upper Palaeolithic would have been generalists with large exploitation territories in both the rugged woodlands and levelled steppe landscapes.
Although it does seem as if the environment favoured the initial success and eventual demise of Neanderthals, it is still unclear whether differences in their resource gathering strategies reflect differences in the environment, in anatomy, or in intelligence.

As of 2017, this list may be considered essentially complete. Sites are sorted west to east, first by country (westernmost site) then within countries. Important remains are in bold. {{hidden|List of Southwest Asian Neanderthals {{navbar|Southwest Asian Neanderthals|plain=1|style=position:absolute; width:auto; right:5em}}| {{Southwest Asian Neanderthals|header=0}}<!-- Please visit the template to edit this table. --> |headerstyle=background:#ccccff |style=text-align:center;}}

The '''old wood effect''' or '''old wood problem''' is a pitfall encountered in the [[archaeology|archaeological]] technique of [[radiocarbon dating]]. A sample will provide misleading or confusing results if materials of different ages are deposited in the same [[archaeological context|context]].
[[Stratification (archeology)|Stratification]] is not always clear-cut in practice. In the case of dating megalithic tombs, indirect evidence for the age of the tomb must always be obtained, because stone (or the time of moving a stone) can not be dated. When a number of objects are recovered from one deposit, the [[terminus post quem]] is based on the dating from the 'youngest' find. Even though other items in the same stratum indicate earlier dates, they may have been deposited at the same time. The deposit must be as young, or younger than the youngest object it contains. Thus excavators look to [[post hole]]s, [[wikt:pit|pits]], or find spots under the [[orthostat]]s for clues to construction dates. The possibility that something (organic) was already in situ must always be considered, especially if the results appear suspiciously early.
The old wood problem can appear in [[marine archaeology]]. Researchers need to check if stumps from a [[Mesolithic]] or [[Palaeolithic]] [[submerged forest]] are to be found in the area. (If they do, the possibility of one sticking up through, e. g., a shipwreck and giving misleading dates must be considered.)
Organic samples which are not derived from the same part of an organism, may show dating variations which blur and obscure the interpretation being attempted. If compelling archaeological reasons for supposing that the ages come from exactly contemporary samples do not exist, then results must be regarded as suspect.<ref>''Discovering Our Past: A Brief Introduction to Archaeology.'' Second Edition. Mayfield Pub. Co., Mountain View, CA. Ashmore, Wendy and Robert J. Sharer (1996)</ref> If there exists no prior reason to believe that two samples are truly of the same age, and even if their ages are statistically indistinguishable, they are as likely to be as far apart in true age as the measured difference between them as they are to be of the same age.<ref>Ward, GK and SR Wilson, 1978, Procedures for Comparing and Combining Radiocarbon Age-Determinations – Critique, ''Archaeometry'', 20 (FEB), pp. 19–31.</ref>
[[Charcoal]] was seen historically as an ideal medium for carbon dating. When long-lived tree species, such as [[oak]] and [[juniper]], are used, however, there is a particular danger of encountering the "old wood" problem. For example, the date being measured may be from [[heartwood]], which is already many centuries old by the time the tree was felled. Another difficulty is that of a possible time-lag between felling and final deposition. The timber may have had an extensive history of use and re-use. A method of ameliorating this problem is to date young growth, if available, for example [[hazel]] twigs. Dating of artefacts using [[Accelerator Mass Spectrometry]] is the gold standard dating method of today; charcoal-sourced dates are seen as unreliable. In establishing the chronology of a site, a representative spread of dates is required before interpretation can be attempted.<ref>Optical and electron microscopy in material culture studies. Killick, D. In ''Learning from Things'', edited by W. David Kingery, pp. 204–230. (Washington: Smithsonian Institution Press) (1996)</ref>

'''''Orange Is the New Black: My Year in a Women's Prison''''' (titled '''''Orange Is the New Black: My Time in a Women's Prison''''' in some editions) is a 2010 memoir by [[Piper Kerman]], which tells the story of her [[money laundering]] and [[illegal drug trade|drug trafficking]] conviction and subsequent year spent in a [[Federal Bureau of Prisons|federal]] [[Incarceration of women in the United States|women's prison]].<ref name="nymag1">{{cite web|last=Humphrey |first=Michael |url=http://nymag.com/daily/intel/2010/03/piper_kerman.html |title=Ex-Convict Piper Kerman on Her Hot New Memoir, Orange Is the New Black |publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]] |date=March 25, 2010 |accessdate=May 8, 2010}}</ref>
The book was adapted into the [[Netflix]] original comedy-drama series ''[[Orange Is the New Black]]''.<ref name=NYT>{{cite web|work=[[The New York Times]]|title=Prison Life, Real and Onscreen|first=Aimee|last=Lee Ball|date=August 2, 2013|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/08/04/fashion/prison-life-real-and-onscreen.html?pagewanted=all&_r=0}}</ref>
==Background==
The memoir details the events which occur as a result of Piper Kerman's involvement with Nora Jansen, a former friend, lover and drug smuggler. In 1993, shortly after her graduation from [[Smith College]], Kerman agreed to accompany Jansen on several trips to Asia and Europe, going as far as carrying a suitcase of laundered money across the Atlantic Ocean before returning to San Francisco to "piece her life back together". In May 1998, Kerman was visited by two Customs agents, and six years later she was sentenced to 15 months in federal prison. After serving time in three different facilities ([[FCI Danbury]], [[Federal Transfer Center, Oklahoma City|FTC Oklahoma City]], and [[MCC Chicago]]), Kerman was released in March 2005.
==Reception== {{expand section|date=July 2014}} Sasha Abramsky of the ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'' stated that the book "documents the author’s attempts to preserve her individuality in the face of a gray, impersonal bureaucracy—one {{sic|based |hide=y|around}} prisoner counts, strip searches, rules governing the minutiae of life, and continual reminders that prisoners, by definition, have no power, no real autonomy."<ref name=Abramskyp3>Abramsky, Sasha. "American Justice." ''[[Columbia Journalism Review]]'', May–June, 2010, Vol.49(1), p.55(3) [Peer Reviewed Journal]. Online: May 1, 2010. Online [http://www.cjr.org/review/american_justice.php?page=3 p. 3]. ([https://www.webcitation.org/6QvhMKV0l Archive]). Retrieved on July 9, 2014. "The juxtaposition between Texas Tough and Orange Is the New Black is fascinating, and makes them well worth reading together."</ref> Abramsky wrote that the book is mostly "a journey of self-discovery, describing how one can find one’s true strengths during moments of adversity" and that it "is more similar to South African anti-apartheid activist [[Albie Sachs]]'s ''Jail Diary'' than it is to, say, [[Mumia Abu-Jamal]]’s denunciatory communiqués from Pennsylvania’s death row."<ref name=Abramskyp2>{{cite news|author=Abramsky, Sasha|title=American Justice|work=[[Columbia Journalism Review]]|date= May–June 2010|volume=49|number=1|pages=55(3)|url=http://www.cjr.org/review/american_justice.php?page=2 | accessdate=July 9, 2014}}</ref>
In her review for ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]'', Jessica Grose argued that the book is not an examination of women within prison but rather a member of the middle-class-transgression genre, in which women from higher level social classes go into situations which are considered degrading. She said that the book should have included Kerman's insight into her own behavior and "A bit of this moral ambiguity would have helped Kerman's memoir a whole lot."<ref name=Grose>Grose, Jessica. "[http://www.slate.com/articles/double_x/doublex/2010/04/whats_a_nice_blonde_like_me_doing_in_prison.single.html What's a Nice Blonde Like Me Doing in Prison?]" ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''. April 8, 2010. Retrieved on April 10, 2016.</ref> June Thomas, also from ''Slate'', cited Grose's review and stated that, "Ultimately, though, the book feels like a well-written, readable stage in Kerman’s rehabilitation."<ref name=ThomasSlate>Thomas, June. "[http://www.slate.com/blogs/browbeat/2013/07/22/orange_is_the_new_black_netflix_tv_show_is_better_than_the_piper_kerman.html How ''Orange Is the New Black'' Improves on the Book]." ''[[Slate (magazine)|Slate]]''. July 22, 2013. Retrieved on April 10, 2016.</ref> Thomas stated that the television show had improved on the book by expanding on Kerman's descriptions of real people and turning them into compelling fictional characters.<ref name=ThomasSlate/>
Writing in the ''[[Journal-Advocate]]'', Tricia Ketchum called the book "not your typical 'I survived prison memoir', referring to Kerman as "spoiled" as she received multiple care packages and money into her commissary.<ref name=Ketchum>{{cite news| title =Memoir details woman's year in prison | work =Tricia Ketchum | publisher =Journal-Advocate | date =3 May 2016 | url =http://www.journal-advocate.com/entertainment/ci_29597205/memoir-details-womans-year-prison-orange-is-new-black-piper-kerman }}</ref> Ketchum concludes, "The best part of this book is the message that it leaves you with: No matter what choices you make, you never realize just how much they will impact the lives of those around you until it is too late."<ref name=Ketchum />
The book was selected by the [[UC Santa Barbara]] Library as its 2015 book for the university-wide reading program "UCSB Reads".<ref name="estrada">{{cite web|last=Estrada |first=Andrea |url=http://www.news.ucsb.edu/2014/014620/ucsb-reads-selects-orange-new-black-piper-kerman#sthash.f8D878jO.dpuf |title='UCSB Reads’ Selects ‘Orange Is the New Black’ by Piper Kerman |publisher=The UC Santa Barbara Current |date=November 24, 2014 |accessdate=Jan 14, 2015}}</ref>

Columbus then visits and names ''[[Saint Thomas, U.S. Virgin Islands|San Tomas]]'' (Saint Thomas) and ''[[Saint John, U.S. Virgin Islands|San Juan]]'' (Saint John). '''Overacting''' (also referred to as '''hamming''' or '''mugging''') refers to acting that is exaggerated. Overacting can be viewed negatively or positively. It is sometimes known as "chewing the [[Theatrical scenery|scenery]]".<ref>[http://www.worldwidewords.org/qa/qa-che2.htm Chew the scenery] ''worldwidewords.org''</ref>
==Uses== Some roles require overly-exaggerated [[character actors|character acting]], particularly those in [[comedy film]]s. For example, the breakthrough roles for [[Jim Carrey]] (in ''[[Ace Ventura: Pet Detective]]'' and ''[[The Mask (film)|The Mask]]'') saw him portray the lead characters in a very flamboyant fashion, as the script demanded. He has played several "straight" roles since.<ref>Gilliver, David. 1998. "[http://gilliver.net/writing/truman.html Film Review: The Truman Show]". Accessed 29 July 2006.</ref>
Overacting may be used to portray an outlandish character, or to stress the [[evil]] characteristics of a [[villain]].<ref name="michael"/> [[Academy Award]] winner [[Gary Oldman]] was almost typecast as a criminal early in his film career:<ref>Sexton, Timothy. [https://web.archive.org/web/20120111121252/http://movies.yahoo.com/news/gary-oldman-avoided-typecasting-weirdo-villain-225700644.html How Gary Oldman Avoided Typecasting as a Weirdo, Villain]. ''[[Yahoo! Movies]]''. [[Wayback Machine]]. 6 December 2011. Retrieved 11 August 2014.</ref> the necessity to express villainous characters in an overtly physical manner led to the cultivation of his "big" acting style,<ref>''[[Peter Travers|Popcorn With Peter Travers]]''. Season 5. Episode 15. 9 December 2011. "People who know you ... we remember the ''big'' Gary Oldman."</ref> which hearkened back to his classical theatre training and would become his trademark.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Roberts|first=Chris|date=August 1999|title=Gary Oldman: A sheep in wolf's clothing|journal=[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]]|publisher=[[IPC Media]]|issue=27}}</ref> Oldman has conceded that his approach involves an element of overacting, saying: "[I]t's my influence on those roles that probably they feel bigger than life and a little over-the-top. I mean, I do go for it a bit as an actor, I must admit."<ref>Gary Oldman interview by [[Terry Gross]]. ''[[Fresh Air]]''. [[NPR|National Public Radio]]. 12 February 1998.</ref>
Oscar and [[Tony Award]]-winning actor [[Al Pacino]], when asked if he overacts, said: "Well, all actors do, in a way. You know what they say: in the theater you have to reach the balcony." Pacino suggested that directors serve to rein in screen performances that are too large.<ref>[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9DGrDN14fRk&t=30s "Extra: Al Pacino, "Scarface" & Overacting"]. [[CBS]]. April 18, 2010. Retrieved February 12, 2017.</ref>
==Reactions== In an article on overacting, ''[[The Independent|Independent]]'' critic Leigh Singer wrote: "Unlike theatre's declamatory projecting to the back row, a 'stagey' performance onscreen isn't a compliment... ultimately, it really is a matter of personal taste."<ref>https://www.independent.co.uk/arts-entertainment/films/features/the-overactors-mad-bad-and-dangerous-to-the-scenery-1984789.html</ref> Jeff Labrecque of ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' argued that "there's a thin line between overacting (bad) and acting that you're overacting (bizarrely genius)";<ref>http://ew.com/article/2009/11/11/nicolas-cage-bad-lieutenant/</ref> the publication at one time gave year-end awards for "best" and "worst" overacting in film, with the aforementioned Oldman and Pacino winning the former for their work in ''[[Léon: The Professional]]'' (1994) and ''[[The Devil's Advocate (1997 film)|The Devil's Advocate]]'' (1997), respectively.<ref>http://www.ew.com/article/1994/12/30/our-take-this-years-movies/</ref><ref>http://ew.com/article/1997/12/26/best-worst-movie-campaigns/</ref> ''[[The Guardian|Guardian]]'' journalist Chris Michael, a proponent of overacting, said: "From [[Hugo Weaving]]'s [[Agent Smith]] to [[Heath Ledger]]'s [[Joker (The Dark Knight)|Joker]] to the entire oeuvre of [[William Shatner]], mannered or stylised acting is an underrated skill."<ref name="michael">https://www.theguardian.com/film/2013/oct/11/why-i-love-overacting</ref>

'''Oxford Text Archive''' ('''OTA''') is an archive of [[electronic text]]s and other literary and language resources which have been created, collected and distributed for the purpose of research into literary and linguistic topics at the [[University of Oxford]], England.
The OTA was founded by Lou Burnard of [[Oxford University Computing Services]] (OUCS) in 1976, initially as the Oxford Archive of Electronic Literature. It is thought to be one of the first archives of digital academic textual resources to collect and distribute materials from other research centres.<ref>{{cite journal|title=Oxford Archive of Electronic Literature|journal=Association for Literary and Linguistic Computing Bulletin|year=1977|volume=5|issue=2|pages=205}}</ref> The OTA continued to be hosted by OUCS (which became subsumed into <ref>[http://www.it.ox.ac.uk/ IT Services], [[University of Oxford]], UK.</ref> in 2012), with associated research and development projects ongoing in the [[Oxford e-Research Centre]]<ref>[http://www.oerc.ox.ac.uk/ Oxford e-Research Centre], [[University of Oxford]], UK.</ref> and the [[Faculty of Linguistics, Philology & Phonetics, University of Oxford]].<ref>[http://www.ling-phil.ox.ac.uk/ Faculty of Linguistics, Philology and Phonetics], University of Oxford, UK</ref> In November 2016, the OTA found a new home in the [[Bodleian Library]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://blogs.it.ox.ac.uk/martinw/2016/10/24/oxford-text-archive-moving-to-the-bodleian-library/|title=Oxford Text Archive moving to the Bodleian Library {{!}} Martin Wynne|website=blogs.it.ox.ac.uk|access-date=2016-11-03}}</ref>
The OTA accepts deposits of primary-source academic electronic editions and linguistic corpora, and is one of the key centres in the emerging European research infrastructure ([[CLARIN]], the Common Language Resources and Technology Infrastructure<ref>[http://www.clarin.eu/ CLARIN], Europe.</ref>). The OTA hosts many scholarly documents marked up according to the latest (P5) edition of the guidelines of the [[Text Encoding Initiative]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.tei-c.org/Activities/Projects/ox01.xml | title=Oxford Text Archive | publisher=Text Encoding Initiative | work=tei-c.org | accessdate=1 September 2012}}</ref> including copies of all of the [[Eighteenth Century Collections Online]] (ECCO) and [[Early English Books Online]] (EEBO) texts which are now in the public domain, linked data. The OTA also manages the distribution of the [[British National Corpus]] (BNC).
From 1996 to 2008, the OTA was one of the centres of the [[Arts and Humanities Data Service]], and hosted [[AHDS Literature, Languages and Linguistics]], a national centre for the support of digital research in literary and linguistic subject areas in the UK.

[[File:Piranesi-4055.jpg|250px|thumb|Plan of the Saepta Julia ([[Giovanni Battista Piranesi|Piranesi]], 1756).]] The '''Saepta Julia''' was a building in the [[Campus Martius]] of [[Rome]], where citizens gathered to cast votes. The building was conceived by [[Julius Caesar]] and dedicated by [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa]] in 26 BCE. The building replaced an older structure, called the [[Ovile]], built as a place for the ''[[comitia tributa]]'' to gather to cast votes.<ref name="Antony Spawforth 19963">Simon Hornblower and Antony Spawforth (eds.), The Oxford Classical Dictionary (1996) — {{ISBN|0-19-866172-X}} ; available online for a fee</ref> The Saepta Julia can be seen on the ''[[Forma Urbis Romae]]'', a map of the city of Rome as it existed in the early 3rd century CE. Part of the original wall of the Saepta Julia can still be seen right next to the Pantheon.
== History == The conception of the Saepta Julia, which also goes by Saepta or Porticus Saeptorum, began during the reign of Julius Caesar. It took the form of a [[quadriporticus]], an architectural feature made popular by Caesar.<ref name="Antony Spawforth 19963"/>
After Caesar's assassination in 44 BCE, work continued on projects that Caesar had set into motion.<ref>Cic. Att 4.16.14</ref> [[Marcus Aemilius Lepidus (triumvir)|Marcus Aemilius Lepidus]], who had supported Caesar before his death, and subsequently aligned with his successor [[Octavian]], took on the continuation of the Saepta Julia building project. The building was finally completed and dedicated by [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa]] in 26 BCE. Agrippa also decorated the building with marble tablets and Greek paintings.<ref>{{cite book|title=Campus Martius: The Field of Mars in the Life of Ancient Rome|last1=Jacobs II|first1=Paul W.|last2=Conlin|first2=Diane Atnally|date=2015|publisher=Cambridge University Press|location=Cambridge|page=107}}</ref>
The [[Great Fire of Rome]] led to its destruction in 80 CE, and was rebuilt sometime before the reign of Domitian.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Silvae 4.5.2|last=Statius|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Restoration also took place under Hadrian, as is evidenced by brick-work and literary sources.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Historia Augusta: Life of Hadrian|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> The building is also attested on a post-[[Constantine the Great|Constantine]] bronze collar of a slave, but there is no known mention of the building in the Middle Ages.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome|last=Platner|first=Samuel|last2=Ashby|first2=Thomas|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1929|isbn=|location=London|pages=460}}</ref>
The Saepta Julia can be seen on the ''[[Forma Urbis Romae]]'', a map of the city of Rome as it existed in the early 3rd century CE. Part of the original wall of the Saepta Julia can still be seen right next to the Pantheon
== Plan == Due to the limited archaeological remains, the majority of archaeological reconstructions are derived from the [[Forma Urbis Romae]] and corresponding literary sources. Located on the Campus Martius, between the [[Baths of Agrippa]] and the [[Serapeum]], the Saepta Julia was a rectangular porticus complex, which extended along the west side of the [[Via lata|Via Lata]] to the Via di S. Marco. It was 310 meters long by 120 meters wide and was built of travertine marble. Two porticoes lay on the east and west of the complex. The north end was a lobby, and the south side connected to the [[Diribitorium]] through an uncolonnaded, broad corridor. The only entrances that have been discerned are minor entrances on the south end of the complex.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome|last=Richardson Jr.|first=Lawrence|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|year=1992|isbn=|location=Baltimore|pages=}}</ref>
Archaeological excavations underneath the [[Doria Pamphilj Gallery|Palazzo Doria]] uncovered multiple travertine piers. While the majority of the piers measured 1.7 meters square, other piers showed a variety of dimensions. This has led some scholars to speculate on the existence of a second floor.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome|last=Platner|first=Samuel|last2=Ashby|first2=Thomas|publisher=Oxford University Press|year=1929|isbn=|location=London|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome|last=Richardson Jr.|first=Lawrence|publisher=Johns Hopkins University|year=1992|isbn=|location=Baltimore|pages=}}</ref>
The Saepta was supplied with water by [[Aqua Virgo]], which supplied the majority of buildings on the Campus Martius.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Water Distribution in Ancient Rome: The Evidence of Frontinus|last=Harry|first=Evans|publisher=University of Michigan Press|year=1997|isbn=|location=Ann Arbor|pages=109}}</ref>
=== Porticus Argonautarum === [[File:The_Pantheon_(III)_(4924153315).jpg|link=https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:The_Pantheon_(III)_(4924153315).jpg|thumb|Western wall of the Porticus Argonautarum]] The [[Porticus Argonautarum]] lined the western side of the Saepta Julia. It was completed by [[Marcus Vipsanius Agrippa|Agrippa]] ca. 25 BCE, and received its name from the artwork it depicted, which showed [[Jason]] and the [[Argonauts]]. A portion of the western wall survives, and is located beside the [[Pantheon, Rome|Pantheon]], and suggests that it was made of brick-faced concrete, and covered in marble.<ref>{{Cite book|title=A New Topographical Dictionary of Ancient Rome|last=Richardson Jr.|first=Lawrence|publisher=Johns Hopkins University Press|year=1992|isbn=|location=Baltimore|pages=312–340}}</ref> Reconstructed by Domitian after the fire of 80 CE, this portico was also part of Hadrian's reconstruction of the entire Saepta Julia.<ref>{{cite book|title=Hadrian and the City of Rome|last1=Boatwright|first1=Mary|date=1987|publisher=Princeton University Press|location=Princeton|page=51}}</ref>
=== Porticus Meleagri === The Porticus Meleagri lined the eastern side of the Saepta Julia. Little remains of the Porticus Meleagri, and location and reconstruction rely primarily on the [[Forma Urbis Romae]]. Although not mentioned, it was most likely constructed during the final decades of the first century BCE, along with the dedication of the Saepta.
== Use == The concept of the Saepta was initially planned by Caesar in place of the earlier [[Ovile]], and was projected as early as 54 BCE, and finished by Agrippa in 26 BCE. In a letter to Atticus, Cicero writes that the building was to be made of marble, with a lofty portico and a roof.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Letters to Atticus 2|last=Cicero|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
The building was initially intended to be used as a voting place for both the [[comitia centuriata]] and the [[Comitia Tributa|comitia tributa]].<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Ruins and Excavations of Ancient Rome: A Companion for Students and Travelers|last=Lanciani|first=Rodolfo|publisher=Houghton, Mifflin and Company|year=1897|isbn=|location=New York|pages=472}}</ref> However, with the diminishing importance of the voting comitias from the Augustan period onward, the building began to be repurposed. Gladiatorial combats were exhibited during the period of Augustus, and the building was also used by the senate as a meeting point.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Life of Augustus 23|last=Suetonius|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>
When Tiberius returned from Germany, after his military procession, he was presented in this building by Augustus.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Life of Tiberius 17|last=Suetonius|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Both Augustus and Caligula used this building for [[naumachia]]e.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Life of Caligula 18|last=Suetonius|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> It was used for gymnastics competitions and exhibitions during the reign of Nero.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Life of Nero 12|last=Suetonius|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> Statius and Martial report that it was used intermittently as a public space for Roman citizens, as well as a market for luxury goods.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Silvae 4.2.6|last=Statius|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Epigrams 2.14.5|last=Martial|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref>

{{lead rewrite|date=May 2016}} '''Sardonicism''' is "the quality or state of being sardonic; an instance of this; a sardonic remark."''Oxford English Dictionary'': "sardonicism". A ''sardonic'' action is one that is "disdainfully or skeptically humorous" or "derisively mocking."{{cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/sardonic|title=Definition of SARDONIC|website=www.merriam-webster.com}} Also, when referring to laughter or a smile, it is "bitter, scornful, mocking". Hence, when referring to a person or a personal attribute, it is "[c]haracterized by or exhibiting bitterness, scorn or mockery."{{Cite web|url=https://en.oxforddictionaries.com/definition/sardonic|title=Definition of sardonic in English by Oxford Dictionaries|website=Oxford Dictionaries {{!}} English|access-date=2018-01-15}} == Origin == Both the origin of the concept and the etymology of the word sardonicism is uncertain, but it appears to stem from the name for the [[Mediterranean Sea|Mediterranean]] island of [[Sardinia]]. The 10th-century [[Byzantine|Byzantine Greek]] encyclopedia ''[[Suda]]'' traces the word's earliest roots to the notion of grinning ({{lang-grc|σαίρω| sairō}}) in the face of danger, or curling one's lips back at evil.{{cite web|url=http://www.stoa.org/sol-bin/search.pl?login=guest&enlogin=guest&db=REAL&field=adlerhw_gr&searchstr=sigma,124|title=SOL Search|website=www.stoa.org}} One explanation for the later alteration to its more familiar form and connection to laughter (supported by the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'') appears to stem from an ancient belief that ingesting the [[Water dropwort#Sardonic grin|''sardonion'']] (σαρδόνιον) plant from [[Sardinia]] (Σαρδώ) would result in convulsions resembling laughter and, ultimately, death.{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/search?q=sardonic |title=Sardonic | Define Sardonic at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |date= |accessdate=2010-03-31}} In ''Theory and History of Folklore'', [[Vladimir Propp]] discusses alleged examples of ritual laughter accompanying death and killing, all involving groups. These he characterized as sardonic laughter:
Among the very ancient [[Sardinians|people of Sardinia]], who were called Sardi or Sardoni, it was customary to kill old people. While killing their old people, the Sardi laughed loudly. This is the origin of notorious sardonic laughter (Eugen Fehrle, 1930). In light of our findings things begin to look different. Laughter accompanies the passage from death to life; it creates life and accompanies birth. Consequently, laughter accompanying killing transforms death into a new birth, nullifies murder as such, and is an act of piety that transforms death into a new life.Vladimir Propp, ''[https://monoskop.org/images/f/f0/Propp_Vladimir_Theory_and_History_of_Folklore.pdf Theory and History of Folklore]'': Ritual laughter in folklore, pp. 134-35. Anthology edited by [[Anatoly Liberman]] (1984).
A root form may first appear in [[Homer]]'s ''[[Odyssey]]'' as the [[Ancient Greek]] ''sardánios'', for scornful laughter.{{cite web|url=http://www.collinsdictionary.com/dictionary/english/sardonic?showCookiePolicy=true|title=Sardonic definition and meaning - Collins English Dictionary|website=www.collinsdictionary.com}} From the {{Lang|el-Latn|sardónios}} evolved the {{lang-la|sardonius}}, thence the {{lang-fr|sardonique}}, and ultimately the familiar English adjectival form, ''sardonic''. == ''Risus sardonicus'' == {{Main|Risus sardonicus}} ''[[Risus sardonicus]]'' is an apparent smile on the face of those who are convulsing because of [[tetanus]], or [[strychnine]] poisoning. From the ''[[Oxford English Dictionary]]'', "A fixed, grin-like expression resulting from spasm of facial muscles, esp. in tetanus." Also:
[Convulsion of the] facial muscles may cause a characteristic expression called ''Risus sardonicus'' (from the Latin for scornful laughter) or ''Risus caninus'' (from the Latin for doglike laughter or grinning). This facial expression has also been observed among patients with tetanus. ''Risus sardonicus'' causes a patient's eyebrows to rise, eyes to bulge, and mouth to retract dramatically, resulting in what has been described as an evil-looking grin.[https://books.google.com/books?id=AgfjGTxPM2MC&pg=PA161&dq=Strychnine+risus&hl=en&sa=X&ei=wB7IU7SHMtKf7Abj9ICoAw&ved=0CCwQ6AEwAA#v=onepage&q=Strychnine%20risus&f=false Holstege, C. et al., ''Criminal Poisoning: Clinical and Forensic Perspectives'', by Christopher Holstege, Thomas Neer, Gregory Saathoff, and Brent Furbee, Jones & Bartlett Learning, 2010, p. 161.]
=== Hemlock water dropwort === In 2009 scientists at the [[University of Eastern Piedmont]] in [[Italy]] claimed to have identified hemlock [[water dropwort]] (''Oenanthe crocata'') as the plant responsible for producing the sardonic grin.{{cite journal|journal = Journal of Natural Products|year = 2009|volume = 72|issue = 5|pages = 962–965|title = Polyacetylenes from Sardinian ''Oenanthe fistulosa'': A Molecular Clue to ''risus sardonicus''|author1=G. Appendino |author2=F. Pollastro |author3=L. Verotta |author4=M. Ballero |author5=A. Romano |author6=P. Wyrembek |author7=K. Szczuraszek |author8=J. W. Mozrzymas |author9=O. Taglialatela-Scafati |last-author-amp=yes |doi = 10.1021/np8007717|pmid = 19245244|pmc = 2685611}} This plant is the candidate for the "sardonic herb", which was a [[neurotoxin|neurotoxic]] plant used for the [[Human sacrifice|ritual killing]] of elderly people in [[Nuragic civilization|pre-Roman Sardinia]]. When these people were unable to support themselves, they were [[Substance intoxication|intoxicated]] with this herb and then dropped from a high rock or beaten to death.[http://www.scientificamerican.com/article.cfm?id=in-brief-aug-09 News Scan Briefs: Killer Smile], Scientific American, August 2009 == See also == {{portal|Psychology}} * [[Sarcasm]] * [[Schadenfreude]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == {{wiktionary|sardonic}} * {{cite web | url=http://www.etymonline.com/index.php?term=sardonic| title=Entry: Online Etymology Dictionary | accessdate=2008-10-30 | work= |publisher= }} [[Category:Greek words and phrases]] [[Category:Humour]] [[Category:Latin words and phrases]] [[Category:Rhetoric]]

page.title: Star polygons in art and culture

revision.text:
{{other uses2|Star}} {{Multiple issues| {{More footnotes|date=September 2009}} {{Lead too short|date=September 2009}} }}
[[Star polygon]]s and polygonal compounds are the basis for numerous figures of significance in [[arts]] and [[culture]]. The figure may be the border or interior of the polygon, or one or more closed polygonal paths that include all of the border and also have some legs crossing the interior. Impressions of [[astronomy|astronomical]] [[stars]] provide the term, but specific uses may exploit the connection or not. Stars often represent the unity of states within a country when they are used as a part of the flag.
==Emblematic use== {{Main|Star (heraldry)}} *In [[heraldry]], a [[star (heraldry)|mullet]] is a star with straight arms and typically five points. A star with wavy rather than straight rays is called an [[estoile]].<ref name="Fox-Davies">{{Cite book |last = Fox-Davies |first = Arthur Charles |author2=Graham Johnston |origyear = 1909|year = 2004 |title = A Complete Guide to Heraldry |publisher = Kessinger Publishing |isbn = 1-4179-0630-8 |pages = 295–296}}</ref> The mullet, used as an [[Charge (heraldry)|heraldic charge]], is the ensign of knightly rank, and every order of knighthood incorporates this symbol in some way. It has traditionally been used in British heraldry as a mark of [[cadency]] for the third son.<ref>{{Cite book |last = Volborth |first = Carl Alexander von |year = 1981 |title = Heraldry: Customs, Rules and Styles |publisher = Blandford Press |location = Poole, England |isbn = 0-7137-0940-5 |page = 80}}</ref> *In Christian art, [[Bruno of Cologne|St. Bruno]] bears a star on his breast; [[Saint Dominic]], [[Humbert of Maroilles|Saint Humbert]] and [[Saint Peter of Alcantara]] have a star on their head or forehead.<ref>{{cite book |last=Brewer |first=E. Cobham |title=The Dictionary of Phrase and Fable |section=Star |location=Ware, Hertfordshire |publisher=Wordsworth Editions Ltd |isbn=1-85326-300-1}}</ref> *The star with six (or less commonly five, sometimes seven) points{{Citation needed|date=September 2009}} is associated with [[Police|law enforcement]] in the [[United States]], and forms the basis of the [[sheriff]]'s badge.
==Five-pointed stars== {{Main|Five-pointed star}} [[File:Five-pointed star.svg|thumb|100px|Five-pointed star]] The five-pointed star, if drawn with points of equal length and angles of 36° at each point, is sometimes termed a '''golden five pointed star'''.<ref name="symbDict5-point">[http://www.symbols.com/encyclopedia/28/2824.html The five-pointed star] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111121634/http://www.symbols.com/encyclopedia/28/2824.html |date=11 November 2006 }} from {{cite book |last=Liungman |first=Carl G. |year=2004 |title=Symbols: Encyclopedia of Western Signs and Ideograms |publisher=HME Publishing |isbn=91-972705-0-4}}. Retrieved 19 July 2006.</ref> If the colinear edges are joined together, a [[pentagram]] is produced, which is the simplest of the [[unicursal hexagram|unicursal]] [[star polygon]]s, and a symbol of [[mysticism|mystical]] and [[magic (paranormal)|magical]] significance. Originally, the five-pointed star (pentangle), forming a pentagram within it, represented the ten tribes of Israel that broke away from the ruling class of Judah, Benjamin, and the Priests.{{Citation needed|date=July 2011}} There are ten "Vav" or "man" that form the five points. A circle was also added around the Israelite Star because it was the letter "Samek" meaning, "death". Today's modern Pagans tend to use all three symbols, rather than making any distinction. The golden five-pointed star is a very common [[ideogram]] in the western world, and has particularly strong associations with military power and war. The Asian giant [[LG Corporation]]'s initials actually stand for "Lucky Goldstar" (and not "Life is Good" as many Westerners are led to believe). Many [[communism|communist]] countries (such as [[People's Republic of China|China]] and [[Vietnam]]) and symbols (the [[hammer and sickle]]) also incorporate [[Red star|five-pointed stars]]. <gallery> <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: Image:Ksstarandcrescent.gif|The Star and Crescent of [[Kappa Sigma]] --> Image:VIIcorpsbadge.png|[[VII Corps (ACW)|Union Army, VII Corps, 3rd Division Badge]] Image:XIIcorpsbadge.png|[[XII Corps (ACW)|Union Army, XII Corps, 3rd Division Badge]] </gallery> The five-pointed star appears in the flags of 35 countries, and also appears commonly in the [[heraldry]] of the [[United States]], and stands in contrast to the [[Vexillology|vexillologically]] rarer [[heptagram|seven-pointed star]].
The five-pointed star occurs in conjunction with a [[crescent]] in the flags of several countries to symbolize [[Islam]], appearing for example as part of the symbol of the [[Ottoman Empire]].
In [[philately]], the five-pointed star signifies stamps that have not been [[postmark]]ed.
The five-pointed star is used as the symbol of the [[People Nation]] alliance of gangs from Chicago.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} [[Bloods (gang)|Blood]] gangs who originated from New York, known as the United Blood Nation, also use this as a symbol as they have emulated the People Nation alliance.{{Citation needed|date=June 2008}} [[File:RWS Tarot 15 Devil.jpg|thumb|A pentagram with a point facing downward was used as a symbol of the [[devil]] in [[Romanticism]] and in modern [[Satanism]].]]
In the Armenian Pantheon, there is a goddess called Astlik/Astghik. In the Armenian language Astgh means star, Astghik - Little Star. Compared with Ishtar, Astara, this goddess' sign should have been the (probably)eight-pointed star. <gallery> Image:Pentagram.svg|The [[pentagram]], a five-pointed star drawn with five straight strokes Image:Star and Crescent.svg|The [[star and crescent]] symbol is mostly shown with five-pointed stars in modern flags, but in the oldest [[Ottoman flag]] of this design as well as the [[flag of Azerbaijan]], the star is eight-pointed. Image:Flag of the United States (1777–1795).svg|The 1777 [[Flag of the United States]] had 13 stars of an unspecified number of points<ref name="fcic">{{Cite web |url=http://www.pueblo.gsa.gov/cic_text/misc/ourflag/history1.htm |title=The History of the Stars and Stripes |work=Federal Citizen Information Center |accessdate=2009-09-15}}</ref> </gallery>
==Six-pointed stars== Several varieties of six-pointed stars are used in Western culture: * If the [[Collinearity|collinear edges]] of a regular six-pointed star are connected, so that two interlaced triangles are formed, a symbol results that is variously known as the [[hexagram]], [[Star of David]], or Shield of David (Magen David). This symbol is most commonly associated with [[Judaism]]. It is also used in [[Christianity]], [[Islam]] and [[Hinduism]], but on a less frequent basis. *The [[Ahmadiyya]] flag, ''Lawa-e-Ahmaddiyat'', contains a six-pointed star, adjacent to a crescent. * The [[Star of Life]], which is a six-armed cross. * The [[Great Seal of the United States]] contains a six-pointed star made up of 13 stars (representing the original 13 colonies). * The municipal [[flag of Chicago]] has four six-pointed stars. * German and German-American [[hex sign]]s and [[Barnstars|barn stars]] often incorporate both five- and six-pointed stars as central themes. * The six-pointed star is used as the symbol for the [[Folk Nation]] alliance of gangs from Chicago. Crip gang members tend to use this symbol also.
Apart from the foresaid mentions, six-pointed star formations are rare as an [[ideograph]] in Western cultures except in the case of law enforcement badges.<ref>[http://www.symbols.com/encyclopedia/28/2826.html The sixpointed star] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061111124629/http://www.symbols.com/encyclopedia/28/2826.html |date=11 November 2006 }} from {{cite book |last=Liungman |first=Carl G. |year=2004 |title=Symbols: Encyclopedia of Western Signs and Ideograms |publisher=HME Publishing |isbn=91-972705-0-4}}. Retrieved 19 July 2006.</ref> In [[astrology]], some formations of a six-pointed star can signify [[fixed star]]s. In some rare instances, it can signify the date of birth on a gravestone, synonymous with the five-point star.
<gallery> File:Star of David.svg|thumb|[[Star of David]] File:Liwa-e-Ahmadiyya 1-2.svg|100|[[Ahmadiyya]] flag File:Greater coat of arms of the United States.svg|[[Great Seal of the United States]] </gallery>
==Seven-pointed stars== ===Political=== A seven-pointed star appears in the [[flag]] and [[heraldry|heraldic]] symbolism of [[Australia]]. In the Australian context, the seven points (also known as the '''Commonwealth Star''', the '''Federation Star''', the '''Seven Point Star''', or the '''Star of Federation''') is a seven-pointed star symbolising the [[Federation of Australia]] which came into force on 1 January 1901. Six points of the Star represent the six [[States and territories of Australia|original states]] of the [[Australia|Commonwealth of Australia]], while the seventh point represents the territories.
The seven-pointed stars stand in contrast to the [[vexillology|vexillologically]] more conventional [[five-pointed star]]s.
The Seal of the [[Cherokee Nation]] has an acute gold seven-pointed star in its seal.
The seven-pointed star is also used as a symbol of the [[Trinitarios]] gang from New York City.
<gallery> Image:Flag of Australia.svg|[[Flag of Australia]] Image:Flag of Jordan.svg|[[Flag of Jordan]] Image:Flag of Iraq 1924.svg| [[Flag of Iraq|1924 Flag of Iraq]] </gallery>
===Heptagram=== {{Main|Heptagram}} A [[heptagram]] or '''septagram''' is a seven-pointed star drawn with seven straight strokes. There are two kinds of heptagrams: * ''Acute heptagram'', the {7/3} [[star polygon]]. * ''Obtuse heptagram'', the {7/2} star polygon.
==Eight-pointed stars== ===Political=== <gallery> Image:Flag of Iraq 1959-1963.svg|[[Flag of Iraq|1959 Flag of Iraq]] Image:Flag of Azerbaijan.svg | [[Flag of Azerbaijan]] Image:Hail flag.jpg|Flag of [[Ha'il]] state (1834-1921) </gallery>
=== Other === The Eight Star used widely in the Arabic states as beautification,{{Vague|reason="in decorative art"?|date=August 2011}} sometimes a similar star to the [[Star of Lakshmi]] also consider as the Arabic star. <gallery> Image:Ashthalakshmi - Star of Laxmi.svg|[[Star of Lakshmi]] Image:ROUB EL HIZB 06DE.svg|[[Rub El Hizb]] </gallery>
A two-color, 8-pointed star associated with the [[American Friends Service Committee]] and other Quaker service groups since the 1870s is sometimes called "the Quaker star". <gallery>Image:Quaker_star-T.svg</gallery>
==Nine-pointed stars== A nine-pointed star is the most common symbol of the [[Baha'i Faith]], the number nine being significant in the religion. <gallery> Image:Bahai star.svg </gallery>
==Twelve-pointed stars== The flag of [[Nauru]] uses a twelve-pointed star representing the 12 tribes on the island. <gallery> Image:Flag of Nauru.svg|[[Flag of Nauru]] </gallery>
==Fourteen-pointed stars== The flag of [[Malaysia]] uses the [[Flag of Malaysia#Federal Star .28Bintang Persekutuan.29|Federal Star]], a fourteen-pointed star representing the unity between the 13 member states and the federal government. <gallery> Image:Flag of Malaysia.svg|[[Flag of Malaysia]] </gallery>
==See also== *[[List of symbolic stars]] *[[commons:Flags with stars|Gallery of flags with stars]] *[[Star (glyph)]]
==References== {{Reflist}} Graham, Dr. O.J. The Six-Pointed Star: Its Origin and Usage 4th ed. {{ISBN|0-9689383-0-2}}
== External links == {{Commons|Star symbol}} * [http://moroccandesign.com/eight-point-star Moroccan Islamic Patterns: The Eight-Point Star] Examining the symbolic meaning of the eight-point star (khatam) in Islamic ornamentation. {{Use dmy dates|date=August 2011}}

{{about|the survey in the [[United States]]|the similar survey in [[Europe]] conducted by the [[European Central Bank]]|ECB Survey of Professional Forecasters}}
The '''Survey of Professional Forecasters''' ('''SPF''') is a quarterly survey of macroeconomic forecasts for the [[economy of the United States]] issued by the [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]]. It is the oldest such survey in the United States.
The survey includes an "anxious index" that estimates the probability of a decline in real GDP.<ref name=anxious>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/anxious-index/|title = The Anxious Index|publisher = [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]]}}</ref>
==History==
The survey began in 1968 and was conducted by the [[American Statistical Association]] (ASA) and the [[National Bureau of Economic Research]] (NBER). The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia took over the survey in 1990.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/|title = Survey of Professional Forecasters|publisher = [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]]|accessdate = April 13, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phil.frb.org/research-and-data/publications/business-review/1993/brnd93dc.pdf|title = Introducing: The Survey of Professional Forecasters|last = Croushure|first = Dean|date = November–December 1993|publisher = ''[[Business Review]]''}}</ref> In its early days (prior to the takeover by the Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia) the survey was often referred to in the academic literature as the ASA-NBER survey.<ref name=academic-bibliography/>
In May 2008, it was announced that SPF would be adding an industry classification variable for its survey respondents, so that researchers could more easily determine how people's forecasts related to the industry they were from.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.phil.frb.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/spf-industry-variable.pdf|title = Introducing: An Industry Classification for the Survey of Professional Forecasters|last = Chew|first = John|last2 = Price|first2 = Calvin|date = May 2008|accessdate = April 13, 2014}}</ref>
==Variables==
The Survey of Professional Forecasters includes variables in the following broad categories:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/data-files/|title = Historical Data Files for the Survey of Professional Forecasters|date = August 10, 2012|accessdate = April 13, 2014|publisher = [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]]}}</ref>
* U.S. business indicators * [[Real GDP]] and its components * [[Consumer price index|CPI]] and PCE inflation * Long-term inflation forecasts * Additional long-term forecasts * Equilibrium unemployment * Probability on ranges (for GDP, inflation, and unemployment measures) * Anxious Index * Implied forecasts
==Reception==
SPF has been used in academic research on forecast accuracy and forecast bias.<ref name=academic-bibliography>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/academic-bibliography.cfm|title = Academic Bibliography|publisher = [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]]|accessdate = April 13, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.icmacentre.ac.uk/pdf/seminar/clements2.pdf|title = An evaluation of the Survey of Professional Forecasters probability distributions of expected inflation and output growth.|last = Clements|first = Michael|date = November 22, 2002|accessdate = April 13, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|title = Differential Interpretation in the Survey of Professional Forecasters|last = Manzan|first = Sebastiano|date = August 2011|doi = 10.1111/j.1538-4616.2011.00404.x|journal = [[Journal of Money, Credit and Banking]]|volume = 43|issue = 5|pages = 993–1017}}</ref>
A 1997 analysis of density forecasts of inflation made in the SPF finds: "The probability of a large negative inflation shock is generally overestimated, and in more recent years the probability of a large shock of either sign is overestimated. Inflation surprises are serially correlated, although agents eventually adapt. Expectations of low inflation are associated with reduced uncertainty. The results suggest several promising directions for future research."<ref>{{cite paper |title = Evaluating Density Forecasts of Inflation: The Survey of Professional Forecasters |first=Francis X. |last=Diebold |first2=Anthony S. |last2=Tay |first3=Kenneth F. |last3=Wallis |work=NBER Working Paper No. 6228 |date=October 1997 |doi=10.3386/w6228 }}</ref>
SPF keeps a record of the bias and error in its own past forecasts online.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/data-files/error-statistics.cfm|title = Forecast Error Statistics for the Survey of Professional Forecasters|publisher = [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]]|accessdate = April 13, 2014}}</ref> Their forecasting track record and the implications of their forecasts have been discussed on business press and blogs, including ''[[Forbes]]'' and the ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/billconerly/2013/09/02/economic-assumptions-for-your-2014-business-plan/|title = Economic Assumptions For Your 2014 Business Plan|last = Conerly|first = Bill|date = September 2, 2013|accessdate = April 21, 2014|publisher = ''[[Forbes]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/economics/2010/08/13/economists-in-philly-fed-survey-more-pessimistic/|title = Economists in Philly Fed Survey More Pessimistic|last = Derby|first = Michael|date = August 13, 2010|accessdate = April 13, 2014|publisher = ''[[Wall Street Journal]]''}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://businessforecastblog.com/the-accuracy-of-macroeconomics-forecasts-survey-of-professional-forecasters/|title = The Accuracy of Macroeconomics Forecasts – Survey of Professional Forecasters|last = Jones|first = Clive|publisher = Business Forecasting|date = February 25, 2014|accessdate = April 13, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.economicgreenfield.com/2013/11/26/philadelphia-fed-4th-quarter-2013-survey-of-professional-forecasters/|title = Philadelphia Fed – 4th Quarter 2013 Survey Of Professional Forecasters|publisher = EconomicGreenfield|last = Kavadas|first = Ted|date = November 26, 2013|accessdate = April 13, 2014}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Economic forecasting]] * [[Greenbook]]: The Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia makes available the Greenbook projections data set in [[Microsoft Excel]] format. This includes only four quarterly Greenbook projections in order to maximize the correspondence and comparability with the Survey of Professional Forecasters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/greenbook-data/philadelphia-data-set.cfm|title = Philadelphia Fed's Greenbook Data Set|publisher = [[Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia]]|accessdate = April 18, 2014}}</ref> * [[ECB Survey of Professional Forecasters]], a similar survey conducted by the [[European Central Bank]] starting 1999. * [[Blue Chip Economic Indicators]] * [[Western Blue Chip Economic Forecast]] * [[Consensus Economics]] * [[Livingston Survey]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * {{official website|http://www.philadelphiafed.org/research-and-data/real-time-center/survey-of-professional-forecasters/}}
